title: Talking with like-minded people creates extreme political views, CU Boulder research finds
content:
If you ’ ve spoken with a like-minded friend about politics recently , you may not realize that your views became more extreme as a result of that conversation .
That ’ s according to new research from the University of Colorado , which found that people underestimate the extent to which their views become polarized after a brief interaction with someone who has similar attitudes .
In essence , people ’ s views become more polarized without them realizing it , said Jessica Keating , a graduate student in CU ’ s psychology and neuroscience department .
“ There is a sense that if we become overly polarized , we get things like deadlock in Congress , we have elections that are contentious and make people angry , ” Keating said . “ The only way to combat polarization in society is to look at the individuals making up those distributions . ”
The paper “ Partisan underestimation of the polarizing influence of group discussion , ” written by Keating and CU professors Leaf Van Boven and Charles Judd , was published in the July edition of the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology .
Prior research has shown that people ’ s attitudes become more extreme after they speak with like-minded others .
Keating ’ s study furthered that research by showing that people often underestimate the effects of those conversations . She found that people misremember their pre-discussion attitudes as having been more extreme — they reconstructed their pre-discussion views to more closely align with their more polarized , post-discussion views .
“ We argue that it ’ s basically impossible to do anything about the problem if you are not first aware of it , ” she said . “ There is little incentive to seek out a diverse array of sources for information if you don ’ t know that having a less diverse array of sources is going to cause these effects . ”
Though her work didn ’ t explore possible solutions to this problem , Keating recommended that people seek out a diverse array of information sources . She said the first step is simply being aware that living in Boulder ’ s liberal bubble could lead a person to have more extreme political views over time .
“ If you only watch Fox News or you only watch MSNBC or you only talk to people who have similar ideas to you , our research suggests that you will , over time , become more extreme in your beliefs , ” she said . “ If you are aware that it can happen , we would urge you to seek out a diverse array of sources . ”
Though her work didn ’ t study how this political polarization would play out in the land of Facebook and Twitter , Keating said she speculated that the results would be similar in virtual conversations .
“ Putting those statements out there and then hearing , in a bit of an echo chamber , from others who share those beliefs , you would get group polarization in that scenario and I would think you would underestimate it , ” she said .
After finishing her undergraduate degree at Smith College , Keating spent five years as an analyst at a Washington , D.C. , polling firm .
Though polls were helpful for understanding how voters felt , they didn ’ t help explain why they felt that way .
Keating wanted to dig deeper , which brought her to CU to work toward a doctorate .
“ Social psychology is really all about the ‘ why , ' ” she said . “ Why do people feel that way ? Why does polarization happen ? Why is there animosity toward the other side ? Why does it matter ? ”
Broadly speaking , her research applies social psychology theory to real-world questions . She ’ s also studying how social psychology concepts such as belonging , grit , mindset and self-control relate to undergraduate retention rates , which CU administrators are trying to improve .
One of Chancellor Phil DiStefano ’ s top priorities is improving CU ’ s six-year graduation rate . To do that , the campus also needs to improve its retention rates , or the number of students who start at CU and return each year .
DiStefano ’ s office funded a year of Keating ’ s research into how CU could potentially improve its retention rate , she said . She ’ s also been working with CU ’ s Housing and Dining Services .
“ We really came at the retention issues from the perspective of CU facing a challenge , and that was a lower-than-desired , six-year graduation rate , ” Keating said . “ We have studied this in social psychology … there are theories about what aspects of a person ’ s personality and environment influence their retention and performance , or their political behavior . ”
